content:
YOU are not using a service that is synchronized to the server storage. So even the read/unread status of email is synchronized. I suggest you get used to getting mail when it arrives, not when you click a button.

I still use POP because for some accounts it meets my needs better than IMAP. avoid exchange and the OWL add-on if at all possible as emulating the exchange web services is not something I want to be doing much of..
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
pdf.js (https://mozilla.github.io/pdf.js/) Ã¨ la libreria di Thunderbird che visualizza i PDF. Questa libreria converte il formato PDF in un suo equivalente HTML che poi Ã¨ visualizzato da Thunderbird. Con file PDF semplici la conversione Ã¨ praticamente perfetta. Con file PDF con caratteristiche tecniche o grafiche avanzante invece possono esserci delle imperfezioni come quella che hai descritto.

Non esiste una soluzione se non quella di attendere gli aggiornamenti di pdf.js. Oppure puoi impostare un diverso programma per aprire i PDF, perdendo perÃ² la comoditÃ  del visualizzatore integrato.

content:
I just had the same issue!

I downgraded Thunderbird using the following commands. The mask command is needed so it wont be auto-updated by Discover or Gnome Software

sudo flatpak update --commit=2151b1e101f1266d135040c142f4c36a7e3373dc772e75a509a38efc39ded993 org.mozilla.Thunderbird flatpak mask org.mozilla.Thunderbird

content:
Two commands solved it for me. thanks to Hammerhead Corvette on AskFedora forums.

flatpak update --commit=2151b1e101f1266d135040c142f4c36a7e3373dc772e75a509a38efc39ded993 org.mozilla.Thunderbird

flatpak update --commit=cbb56c7054d2893acf77b5cdfd0adc0588adc090edb49a92d79ac6e8f7983ad4 org.mozilla.Thunderbird.Locale

Hey presto, TB opens, fixed. Can't wait for a replacement for TB to turn up, I hate having no alternatives (with local folder abilities)

In Thunderbird trova la cartella chiamata Cartelle locali e crea al suo interno una o piÃ¹ cartelle per contenere la posta dell'account eliminato. Sposta poi la posta in queste cartelle e controlla che sia tutto corretto. Infine elimina l'account da Menu > Impostazioni account

content: If the deleted messages are in Trash, empty Trash and compact it from the folder context menu, then compact the Sent folder. Deleting a file just marks it for removal and removes it from view, but compacting removes it permanently.
creator: sfhowes

content: If the drive can be accessed, look for the root drive:\users\<your id>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird if that appears intact, the thunderbird folder is the one to copy as it has everything. On rebuilt or new PC, assuming thunderbird is installed... - exit thunderbird if running - copy the thunderbird folder to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming to overwrite the existing thunderbird (default) folder. - start thunderbird If there were no problems with the profile, all will be okay. If not, components can be salvaged, and I'll wait for your post after doing the above.
creator: davidsk

content: The good news is that IMAP auto populates. That is, when you reinstall an IMAP account, all messages immediately appear. There is no need to copy them for the purpose of moving to new PC. This is because the messages reside on the server and only headers on the PC.
creator: davidsk

content:
Not sure if I made it clear enough in the original question, sorry - this is actually about moving emails from one server to another. I need to put the messages somewhere else while opening a new server which will then be keyed to the same account details, but will not have the messages.

I think I've figured it out though, I'm gonna use local folders on Thunderbird to hold the messages from the old server, and then on connecting to the new server I'll copy them over to that.
creator: samninja64

content: Ok, now I understand. I concur to your strategy with my comments: - first, check account settings>synchronization&storage to verify that all folders can be downloaded - now, click file>offline>download to ensure that all IMAP messages are fully downloaded to the PC - I would then exit thunderbird and copy the message folders to external drive via windows file explorer and then move them to the Local Folders area in profile. I can give details on that, if needed. - now, after creating the new IMAP server account, you can upload the saved messages. Since IMAP was not designed to do that dance, it can be problematic, so I suggest creating a manual filter to copy messages from local folders to the IMAP account, and then to spot check to ensure that the transfer was successful.
creator: davidsk

content: If your account is actually IMAP (look at Server Type in Account Settings), then right-click the account in the Folder Pane, Subscribe..., Refresh, and check the boxes for the desired folders.
creator: sfhowes

content: Thank you for the reply. I followed your advice but it did not correct my issue. I suspect that they are still "hiding" in a folder in my old profile but I don't know how to view them. Do I need to create another profile with POP or can they bee seen from my current IMAP profile?
creator: gwheelermd

content: Were the folder created under Local Folders or as subfolders of the POP account? Are they in a different profile than the current one? Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder, to open the current profile in File/ Explorer, then go up one level to Profiles to see if there's another profile, then look in the Mail/<popservername> and Mail/Local Folders locations of the old profile.

content: Just an observation, as I do not have a fix for your: some email providers, such as Gmail, have settings that cause deletes to be immediately deleted. You should also check your own settings to see what your intended disposition is. ALSO, you posted this twice. Please just post once.

content: My experience with Linux is that software package installations depend on the distributor of the package. For Linux update procedures, I suggest visiting a Linux user forum. I say that because I have seen multiple Linux users post their frustration here because they did an update from a different distribution and it was installed in a different location. Personally, being only a casual Linux user, I gave up in trying to install by myself and I wait until a distribution is eventually available. My Linux PC is at 115.8 and I'm sure it will eventually get an update. Not a good answer, I know, but that's been my experience. Others may have better experiences.
creator: davidsk

content: You're mostly right: - click account settings for the account, and then the synchronization&storage menu to check the advanced tab that the desired folders are available for offline access - then, click file>offline>download to ensure all messages are download. - from here, I suggest exiting thunderbird and copying to external media via windows file explorer and then copy to the Local Folders section of the profile. Let me know if you need instructions.
creator: davidsk
